technical_concept:
touch — creates empty files. You're literally touching a file into existence.
echo — prints text to the screen.
> — the redirect operator. echo "hello" > file.txt pours text into a file (replacing what was there).
cat — short for concatenate. Spills a file's contents onto your screen.
cp — copies files: cp source dest.
mv — moves or renames files: mv old new.
rm — deletes files permanently. No recycle bin. Once gone, it's gone forever.

Bonus: use ; to chain commands on one line — echo hi > a.txt; cp a.txt b.txt does both in sequence.

code_example.code:
touch notes.txt
echo "Hello World" > notes.txt
cat notes.txt
# Hello World

cp notes.txt backup.txt
mv backup.txt archive.txt
rm notes.txt

challenge.task: Create a file called 'signal.txt' with the text 'SOS' inside it, then make a copy called 'backup.txt'.
challenge.hint: You need two steps: write text into a file, then copy it. Use ';' to chain commands on one line.

dialogue.line: Good — you've set up camp. Now you need supplies. In this world, files are your resources. 'touch' creates an empty one — you're literally touching a file into existence, like conjuring a blank notebook from thin air.
So 'touch water.txt' creates a file called water.txt? What good is an empty notebook?

You fill it with 'echo'. 'echo "fresh spring"' prints text to the screen. But the magic is the '>' operator — it redirects that text INTO a file. 'echo "fresh spring" > water.txt' pours your words into water.txt. Think of '>' as an arrow pointing where the text should go.
And how do I read it back?

'cat water.txt' — short for 'concatenate', but think of it as the file coughing up its contents onto your screen. Quick and dirty, no editor needed. Now the critical part: 'cp' duplicates resources. 'cp water.txt reserve.txt' — instant backup. 'mv' moves or renames. And 'rm'...
Permanently. No recycling bin out here in the wilderness. Once something is gone, it's gone. Like fire consuming paper. Always make backups before deleting.
What if I need to do two things in a row?

Use a semicolon — ';'. It chains commands on one line: 'echo hello > note.txt; cat note.txt' creates the file and reads it back, one after the other. Think of ';' as saying 'do this, then do that.' Now — create a signal file with 'SOS' inside and back it up. We might need to call for help.
Alright Ghost, time to learn file craft. In the field, you need to create files, read them, copy them, and — most importantly — destroy them without a trace.
How do I create a file?

'touch' — you touch a file into existence. Empty, clean, untraceable. Like placing a blank envelope at a dead drop. But an empty file is useless. 'echo "message"' prints text, and '>' redirects it into a file. 'echo "coordinates" > drop.txt' — now your envelope has intel inside.
So '>' is the redirect — it points where the output goes?

Exactly. Without '>', echo just prints to screen. With '>', it writes to a file. Now for reading: 'cat file.txt' — short for concatenate, but think of it as forcing the file to confess its contents. Quick, silent, no editor trail.

'cp' duplicates — 'cp original.txt copy.txt'. 'mv' relocates or renames — perfect for covering tracks. And 'rm' — remove. Gone. No recycle bin, no forensic recovery. In our line of work, that's a feature, not a bug. But always duplicate before you destroy — a good operative never loses the only copy.
What if I need to do two things in one move?

Semicolon — ';'. It chains commands: 'echo intel > file.txt; cp file.txt backup.txt'. First one runs, then the next. No hesitation. Now — create a signal file with 'SOS' inside and back it up. We might need that intel later.
